DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the cellular therapy product cell type.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Utilization of specific cells, modified or not, for treatment of diseases. Donor lymphocyte infusion is a type of cellular therapy._A thing produced by or resulting from a process. EXAMPLE(S): drug, device. The FDA list of regulated products: animal and human drugs; therapeutic biologics; allergenics; cell, tissue and gene therapy products; blood components; blood derivative products; devices; and animal (pets and livestock) and human food/feed (medicated and un-medicated); cosmetics; pet treats; and dietary supplements.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Utilization of specific cells modified or not for treatment of diseases. Donor lymphocyte infusion is a type of cellular therapy.

Concepts.definition: Utilization of specific cells, modified or not, for treatment of diseases. Donor lymphocyte infusion is a type of cellular therapy.

Property.preferredDefinition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.

Concepts.definition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Body tissue, region, surface, cavity, fluid, organ, or collection of organs.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The individual unit that makes up all of the tissues of the body. All living things are made up of one or more cells._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)

Concepts.definition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

Concepts.definition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing hemoglobin whose function is to transport oxygen.

Concepts.definition: A blood cell specialized for oxygen transport, having a high concentration of hemoglobin in the cytoplasm. They are biconcave, anucleate discs, with a 6-8um diameter in humans.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

Concepts.definition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (MYE-eh-loyd) Pertaining to, derived from, or manifesting certain features of the bone marrow. In some cases also pertains to certain types of non-lymphocyte white blood cells found in the bone marrow, including granulocyte, monocyte, and platelet lineages. Also called myelogenous.: Not characterized in any other way.

Concepts.definition: A type of white blood cell. Neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils are granulocytes.
Not characterized in any other way.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood; contain a large, oval or somewhat indented nucleus surrounded by voluminous cytoplasm and numerous organelles.

Concepts.definition: Large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood; contain a large, oval or somewhat indented nucleus surrounded by voluminous cytoplasm and numerous organelles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lymphoid cells concerned with humoral immunity. They are short-lived cells resembling bursa-derived lymphocytes of birds in their production of immunoglobulin upon appropriate stimulation.

Concepts.definition: Immunologically important lymphocyte that is not thymus-dependent, is either short-lived and naive or long-lived and of memory phenotype, and resembles the bursa-derived lymphocyte of birds in that it is responsible for the production of immunoglobulins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of leukocyte with a multilobed nucleus and cytoplasmic granules. The unique morphology of the nucleus has led to their also being known as polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMLs or PMNs). Granulocytes are subdivided according to the staining properties of their granules into eosinophils (red with acidic dye), basophils (blue with basic dye), and neutrophils (not amenable to staining with either acidic or basic dyes).

Concepts.definition: A type of leukocyte with a multilobed nucleus and cytoplasmic granules. The unique morphology of the nucleus has led to their also being known as polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMLs or PMNs). Granulocytes are subdivided according to the staining properties of their granules into eosinophils (red with acidic dye), basophils (blue with basic dye), and neutrophils (not amenable to staining with either acidic or basic dyes).

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Changed to current NCIt definition per NMDP request. mc 9/9/2020

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of immune cell that has granules (small particles) with enzymes that can kill tumor cells or cells infected with a virus. A natural killer cell is a type of white blood cell.

Concepts.definition: Natural killer cells are cells that resemble large granular lymphocytes.  They do not express markers of either T or B cell lineage. They are positive for CD16, CD56, and CD 94.  These cells do possess Fc receptors for IgG and can kill target cells using antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity. They can also use perforin to kill cells in the absence of antibody and killing may occur without previous sensitization.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.: A mixture of cells possessing a single nucleus, including monocytes and lymphocytes; blood leukocytes from which granulocytes have been separated and removed.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
A mixture of cells possessing a single nucleus, including monocytes and lymphocytes; blood leukocytes from which granulocytes have been separated and removed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not processed or refined.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: Including all components without exception; constituting the full amount or extent or duration; complete.: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

Concepts.definition: Not processed or refined.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Including all components without exception; constituting the full amount or extent or duration; complete.
The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One type of white blood cell that attacks virus-infected cells, foreign cells, and cancer cells.  T cells also produce a number of substances that regulate the immune response.

Concepts.definition: A thymocyte-derived lymphocyte of immunological importance that is long-lived (months to years) and is responsible for cell-mediated immunity. T lymphocyte cells form rosettes with sheep erythrocytes and, in the presence of transforming agents (mitogens), differentiate and divide. These cells have the characteristic T3 surface marker and may be further divided into subsets according to function, such as helper, cytotoxic, etc.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An undifferentiated stromal cell with the ability to develop into the cells that form distinct mesenchymal tissues; such as bone, muscle, connective tissue, blood vessels, and lymphatic tissue.

Concepts.definition: An undifferentiated stromal cell with the ability to develop into the cells that form distinct mesenchymal tissues; such as bone, muscle, connective tissue, blood vessels, and lymphatic tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the CD34 expressing cells per unit in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of CD34 expressing cells present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subset of T-lymphocytes that express the CD8 surface glycoprotein and bind epitopes that are part of class I histocompatibility molecules. CD8-positive T-lymphocytes include cytotoxic T-lymphocytes and CD8+ suppressor T-lymphocytes.

Concepts.definition: A subset of T-lymphocytes that express the CD8 surface glycoprotein and bind epitopes that are part of class I histocompatibility molecules. CD8-positive T-lymphocytes include cytotoxic T-lymphocytes and CD8+ suppressor T-lymphocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of white blood cell that helps stimulate immune system reactions.  Helper T cells help activate cytotoxic T cells and macrophages by secreting cytokines. They also stimulate B cells to make antibodies.

Concepts.definition: A type of white blood cell that helps stimulate immune system reactions.  Helper T cells help activate cytotoxic T cells and macrophages by secreting cytokines. They also stimulate B cells to make antibodies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of immune cell that is made in the bone marrow and is found in the blood and in lymph tissue. The two main types of lymphocytes are B lymphocytes and T lymphocytes. B lymphocytes make antibodies, and T lymphocytes help kill tumor cells and help control immune responses. A lymphocyte is a type of white blood cell.

Concepts.definition: White blood cells formed in the body's lymphoid tissue. The nucleus is round or ovoid with coarse, irregularly clumped chromatin while the cytoplasm is typically pale blue with azurophilic (if any) granules. Most lymphocytes can be classified as either T or B (with subpopulations of each); those with characteristics of neither major class are called null cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A class of neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system. Oligodendroglia may be called interfascicular, perivascular, or perineuronal satellite cells according to their location. The most important recognized function of these cells is the formation of the insulating myelin sheaths of axons in the central nervous system. (MeSH)

Concepts.definition: A type of large glial cell located in the central nervous system that produces myelin as its main function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pancreatic cell that produces and secretes hormones such as insulin and glucagon.

Concepts.definition: A pancreatic cell that produces and secretes hormones such as insulin and glucagon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Multipotent progenitor cells that are found in the fetal and adult heart that provide the myocardium with limited regenerating capability.

Concepts.definition: Multipotent progenitor cells that are found in the fetal and adult heart that provide the myocardium with limited regenerating capability.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Mesenchymal stem cells isolated from umbilical cord blood capable of high proliferation potential and colony formation capacity in vitro and the ability to proliferate and differentiate to an osteogenic phenotype in culture.

Concepts.definition: Mesenchymal stem cells isolated from umbilical cord blood capable of high proliferation potential and colony formation capacity in vitro and the ability to proliferate and differentiate to an osteogenic phenotype in culture.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Circulating cells that express a variety of cell surface markers similar to those expressed by vascular endothelial cells, adhere to endothelium at sites of hypoxia or ischemia, and participate in new vessel formation.

Concepts.definition: Circulating cells that express a variety of cell surface markers similar to those expressed by vascular endothelial cells, adhere to endothelium at sites of hypoxia or ischemia, and participate in new vessel formation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.: Possessing a single nucleus.: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.
Possessing a single nucleus.
The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Dendritic Cell And/Or Neoplastic Cell Hybridoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Dendritic Cell And/Or Neoplastic Cell Hybridoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Immunocompetent cells of the lymphoid and hemopoietic systems and skin. They function morphologically and phenotypically by presenting or processing antigens, thereby stimulating cellular immunity. They represent the most potent antigen-presenting cells and, therefore, play a critical role in the primary T cell immune response.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: Cells of, or derived from, a tumor.: A tumor of hybrid cells used in the in vitro production of specific monoclonal antibodies; produced by fusion of an established tissue culture line of lymphocyte tumor cells (e.g., mouse plasmacytoma cells) and specific antibody-producing cells (e.g., splenocytes from specifically immunized mice); fusions are accomplished by use of polyethylene glycol or other methods.

Concepts.definition: Immunocompetent cells of the lymphoid and hemopoietic systems and skin. They function morphologically and phenotypically by presenting or processing antigens, thereby stimulating cellular immunity. They represent the most potent antigen-presenting cells and, therefore, play a critical role in the primary T cell immune response.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Cells of, or derived from, a tumor.

A tumor of hybrid cells used in the in vitro production of specific monoclonal antibodies; produced by fusion of an established tissue culture line of lymphocyte tumor cells (e.g., mouse plasmacytoma cells) and specific antibody-producing cells (e.g., splenocytes from specifically immunized mice); fusions are accomplished by use of polyethylene glycol or other methods.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Immunized T-lymphocytes which can directly destroy appropriate target cells. These cytotoxic lymphocytes may be generated in vitro in mixed lymphocyte cultures (MLC), in vivo during a graft-versus-host (GVH) reaction, or after immunization with an allograft, tumor cell or virally transformed or chemically modified target cell. These cells are distinct from natural killer cells and from killer cells mediating antibody-dependent cell cytotoxicity.

Concepts.definition: Immunized T-lymphocytes which can directly destroy appropriate target cells. These cytotoxic lymphocytes may be generated in vitro in mixed lymphocyte cultures (MLC), in vivo during a graft-versus-host (GVH) reaction, or after immunization with an allograft, tumor cell or virally transformed or chemically modified target cell. These cells are distinct from natural killer cells and from killer cells mediating antibody-dependent cell cytotoxicity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that the CD3 complex has been detected in a sample.: A thymocyte-derived lymphocyte of immunological importance that is long-lived (months to years) and is responsible for cell-mediated immunity. T lymphocyte cells form rosettes with sheep erythrocytes and, in the presence of transforming agents (mitogens), differentiate and divide. These cells have the characteristic T3 surface marker and may be further divided into subsets according to function, such as helper, cytotoxic, etc.

Concepts.definition: An indication that the CD3 complex has been detected in a sample.

A thymocyte-derived lymphocyte of immunological importance that is long-lived (months to years) and is responsible for cell-mediated immunity. T lymphocyte cells form rosettes with sheep erythrocytes and, in the presence of transforming agents (mitogens), differentiate and divide. These cells have the characteristic T3 surface marker and may be further divided into subsets according to function, such as helper, cytotoxic, etc.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Blood cells that are devoid of hemoglobin, capable of ameboid motion and phagocytosis, and act as the principal components of the immune system.

Concepts.definition: Blood cells that are devoid of hemoglobin, capable of ameboid motion and phagocytosis, and act as the principal components of the immune system.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A population of CD4+, CD25-, and FoxP3- T-lymphocytes that are involved in immunotolerance. These cells secrete the immunosuppressive cytokines, tumor growth factor-beta (TGF-B) and interleukin-10, and may induce cell cycle arrest or apoptosis in effector T-cells.

Concepts.definition: A population of CD4+, CD25-, and FoxP3- T-lymphocytes that are involved in immunotolerance. These cells secrete the immunosuppressive cytokines, tumor growth factor-beta (TGF-B) and interleukin-10, and may induce cell cycle arrest or apoptosis in effector T-cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Blood that has not been separated into its various components; blood that has not been modified except for the addition of an anticoagulant._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Concepts.definition: Blood that has not been separated into its various components; blood that has not been modified except for the addition of an anticoagulant.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates that CD33 expression has been detected in a sample._Cells which include the monocytes and the granulocytes.

Concepts.definition: Indicates that CD33 expression has been detected in a sample.
Cells which include the monocytes and the granulocytes.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Body tissue, region, surface, cavity, fluid, organ, or collection of organs.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid. Cells are highly variable and specialized in both structure and function, though all must at some stage replicate proteins and nucleic acids, utilize energy, and reproduce themselves.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
